response.answer_text: I mean.. I personally wouldn’t consider them dangerous as I live half way across the world to them, would more than likely never have a face to face encounter with one, and I’ve got more chance being killed by my own dog than I do a Lion. But, if you was to some how come across one on your own, whether that be in a zoo, in the wild, at a circus etc. And you’re unarmed, then I’d imagine they’re pretty dangerous… Dogs kill much more people a year than most wild animals do, but you’ve got much more chance fighting off a dog than you have a Lion. They’re more than twice your weight, have knives attached to all of their feet, have teeth the length of your middle finger and have more power in one leg than you have in your entire body. I don’t know how accurate that last one was to be honest..  But by looking at this photo, I wouldn’t be surprised if it’s true.. I mean, look at them fricken muscles in his legs. That’s insane. So in terms of how likely you are to die from a Lion attack, they’re not very dangerous, you’re actually MUCH more likely to be killed by a car or by drowning.. you’re even more likely to die from accidentally eating something you didn’t know you was allergic to. In terms of how dangerous they are when confronted by one and it decides to attack, my guess is that 99.9% of people won’t make it out alive. Just to finish off, here are some statistics about how some deaths occur a year: Car crash: 1,300,000 (worldwide statistic) Suicide: 800,000 Drowning: 300,000+ Wildfires: 300,000+ Snakes: 50,000 Dogs: 20,000 (these aren’t all maulings, but deaths caused by infectious bites) Crocodile: 1000 Hippopotamus: 500 Lions: 100–250 (numbers vary a bit with Lions) Lightning strike: 30+ Wolves: 10 Sharks: 10 I’m not 100% sure how accurate these all are, some are based on just one country, some are based world wide but regardless, you get my point. Hope this helped. Sources: http://asirt.org/Initiatives/Informing-Road-Users/Road-Safety-Facts/Road-Crash-Statistics What Animals Kill The Most Humans Each Year?

I need clarification on a few points (see my comment) to get into details, but if we assume that you mean wild lions, and the answer for “To whom/what” is to villagers on the borders of lion territory, we can start there. Lions are responsible for 250 deaths every year.[1] Lions who are hurt, or who are just really hungry, will turn to killing humans (we’re very slow and easy to digest, but we aren’t their natural prey). As for taming lions for entertainment: Lions can be trained, but never fully tamed. And while many of the same techniques used to train dogs are used to train lions, it is not that easy.[2] We’ve bred dogs to be our companions for tens of thousands of years. We have not bred lions for behavior. Also, lion trainers raise their lions from the time they are still cubs. That forces a bond.
